title: Complete Dashavatara Ganjifa Playing Card Set & Box Dashavatara Ganjifa Playing Card Box

  physical_appearance: The image depicts a box. The sides and the edges of the box have been worn out. Each exterior face of the box is predominantly red
 surrounded by a yellow with dots painted on it as the motif. An image of a Hindu avatar of Vishnu
 in a seated position
 is depicted on each side of the box.

  subject_terms_1: dots Hinduism recreation card games (game sets) entertaining cultural diffusion avatara

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Boxes Culture diffusion Card games Avatars (Religion) Hinduism Amusements

  subject_terms_3: Hinduism

  sgcool_label_text: Ganjifa is pan-Indian
 played in its various forms in Indian regions including Maharashtra
 Rajasthan
 Bengal
 Orissa
 Karnataka
 among others. The ganjifa game of cards originated in Persia but it really flourished in India where the game developed in various forms. Meanwhile
 in Persia
 the game largely died out. Initially in India
 the game was played by the Mughals of northern India
 but it soon spread to most parts of the country. The proposed set underscore a rare aspect of Indian heritage – a craft tradition akin to miniature painting and a lesser known Indian game.

metadata.title_text: Complete Dashavatara Ganjifa Playing Card Set & Box Dashavatara Ganjifa Playing Card Box
metadata.physical_appearance: The image depicts a box. The sides and the edges of the box have been worn out. Each exterior face of the box is predominantly red, surrounded by a yellow with dots painted on it as the motif. An image of a Hindu avatar of Vishnu, in a seated position, is depicted on each side of the box.
metadata.subject_terms_1: dots Hinduism recreation card games (game sets) entertaining cultural diffusion avatara
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Boxes Culture diffusion Card games Avatars (Religion) Hinduism Amusements
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Ganjifa is pan-Indian, played in its various forms in Indian regions including Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Bengal, Orissa, Karnataka, among others. The ganjifa game of cards originated in Persia but it really flourished in India where the game developed in various forms. Meanwhile, in Persia, the game largely died out. Initially in India, the game was played by the Mughals of northern India, but it soon spread to most parts of the country. The proposed set underscore a rare aspect of Indian heritage – a craft tradition akin to miniature painting and a lesser known Indian game.
